worst.explanation: Resizing the array and shifting $n$ elements are each $O(n)$.

average.explanation: You always have to shift $n$ elements to the right.

best.explanation: You always have to shift $n$ elements to the right.

worst.explanation: Typically constant time, except for the rare case where you have to resize.

worst (unamortized).explanation: If the array is full, you have to resize it by making a new array.

average.explanation: No shifting is needed except for an occasional array resize.

best.explanation: No shifting is needed because the array is not full.

worst.explanation: Resizing the array and shifting $n$ elements are each $O(n)$.

average.explanation: Some elements will be shifted to the right; on average, $n/2$ will.

best.explanation: Adding to the back of the array.

all cases.explanation: You always have to shift $n$ elements to the left.
No shifting or resizing is ever needed.

worst.explanation: If you remove the first element, You have to shift $n$ elements to the left.

average.explanation: You have to shift all elements after the index to the left.

best.explanation: If you remove the last element, you don't have to shift any elements.

all cases.explanation: Create a new node, set its next pointer to the current head, and make the new node the head.
Create a new node, set the tail's next pointer to the new node, and make the new node the tail.

worst.explanation: Traversing to the second-to-last index is $O(n)$, and initializing and inserting the new node is $O(1)$.

average.explanation: Most elements are in the middle. The runtime to traverse to a middle index increases linearly as the data grows.

best.explanation: Adding at the tail or head is an $O(1)$ operation.

all cases.explanation: Set the head pointer to be at the second node.

worst.explanation: You have to traverse to the end of the list to make the second-to-last node the tail.

average.explanation: You have to traverse to the end of the list to make the second-to-last node the tail.

best.explanation: If the list has one element (which is both head and tail), simply clear the list.

worst.explanation: Traversing to the index is $O(n)$, while altering the pointers to remove the node is $O(1)$.

average.explanation: Traversing to the index is $O(n)$, while altering the pointers to remove the node is $O(1)$.

best.explanation: If index is 0 or the list has one element, time complexity is the same as removeFromFront().

all cases.explanation: When adding to the front of an SLL, we have direct access to the head node.
Without a tail pointer, adding to the back of an SLL requires traversal through the entire list to reach the end.

worst.explanation: To add at the last index, we have to traverse $n$ nodes starting at the head.

average.explanation: To add at an index near the middle, we have to traverse $n/2$ nodes starting at the head.

best.explanation: If adding at the front, the operation is $O(1)$ due to direct access to the head pointer.
best.example: head -> [NEW] -> ['a'] -> ['b'] -> ..~|| OR ||~.. -> [$n - 1$] -> [$n$] -> [NEW] <- tail  // addAtIndex(0 OR size, NEW)

all cases.explanation: Removing from the front of an SLL is always $O(1)$, as you have direct access to the head pointer.
To remove the last node, we have to traverse to the second-to-last node, which is approximately $n$ steps.

worst.explanation: To remove the last node, we have to traverse to the second-to-last node, which is approximately $n$ steps.

average.explanation: On average, traversing to an index near the middle takes $n/2$ steps.

best.explanation: If removing from the front, the operation is $O(1)$ as it only requires updating the head pointer.

all cases.explanation: Accessing the head and adjusting pointers takes constant time.
Accessing the tail and adjusting pointers takes constant time.

worst.explanation: May need to iterate $n/2$ times to reach the node if the index is in the middle.

average.explanation: On average, the index is between the head and tail, requiring more iterations as the data grows.

best.explanation: Adding at the head and tail is easy with direct access using their pointers.

all cases.explanation: Accessing the head and adjusting pointers takes constant time.
Accessing the tail and adjusting pointers takes constant time.

worst.explanation: May need to iterate $n/2$ times to reach the node if the index is in the middle.

average.explanation: On average, the index is between the head and tail, requiring more iterations as the data grows.

best.explanation: Removing at the head and tail is easy with direct access using their pointers.

all cases.explanation: Accessing the head and adjusting the head pointer in a circular structure always takes constant time.

By inserting a new node in the 2nd position from the front, copying the head's data to this new node, putting the new data in the head node, and then moving the head pointer forward by one, we effectively add to the back in constant time.

worst.explanation: Traversing to the target index requires visiting all $n$ nodes in the worst case.

average.explanation: On average, traversing to an index near the middle is $n/2$ operations, and increases linearly as the data grows.

best.explanation: Inserting at the front or back.

all cases.explanation: Removing the head and adjusting pointers takes constant time.
Traversing to find the node before the tail requires visiting about $n$ nodes.

worst.explanation: Traversing to the target index requires visiting about $n$ nodes in the worst case.

average.explanation: On average, traversing to an index near the middle is $n/2$ operations, and increases linearly as the data grows.

best.explanation: Removing the front or back.

worst.explanation: If a resize is triggered, $n$ elements must be copied to the new backing array.

average.explanation: No elements need to be shifted when adding to the back. Additionally, the average case doesn't involve resizing.

best.explanation: No elements need to be shifted when adding to the back. Additionally, the best case doesn't involve resizing.

all cases.explanation: No elements need to be shifted when removing from back.
Create and link a new node. No shifting occurs.
Just remove the head node. No shifting occurs.

worst.explanation: If a resize is triggered, $n$ elements must be copied to the new backing array.

average.explanation: No elements need to be shifted when adding to the back. Additionally, the average case doesn't involve resizing.

best.explanation: No elements need to be shifted when adding to the back. Additionally, the best case doesn't involve resizing.

all cases.explanation: Due to the circular array implementation, no shifting is needed.
Create and link a new node using the tail. No traversal or shifting is needed.
Just remove the head node. No shifting occurs.

worst.explanation: Rarely, the array needs to be resized.

worst (unamortized).explanation: In this case, the array is being resized because the array is full.

average.explanation: Have a front pointer, and usually we don't need to resize.

best.explanation: Circular arrays do not shift elements; the data wraps around and we have a front pointer.

worst.explanation: Rarely, the array needs to be resized.

worst (unamortized).explanation: In this case, the array is being resized because the array is full.

average.explanation: Usually we don't need to resize.

best.explanation: Do not need to resize because the array is not full.

all cases.explanation: Never need to resize when removing from an array. Simply move the front pointer forward.
Never need to resize when removing from an array.
Have direct access to the head.
Have direct access to the tail.
Have direct access to the head.
Have direct access to the tail, which has a previous pointer.

worst.explanation: In a degenerate tree, you have to traverse around $n$ nodes.

average.explanation: An average BST is relatively balanced, so you have to traverse around $log n$ nodes.

best.explanation: In a balanced tree, you have to traverse $log n$ nodes.

worst.explanation: In a degenerate tree, you have to traverse around $n$ nodes to remove a leaf.

average.explanation: An average BST is relatively balanced, so you have to traverse around $log n$ nodes.

best.explanation: In a balanced tree, you have to traverse $log n$ nodes.

worst.explanation: In a degenerate tree, you have to traverse around $n$ nodes.

average.explanation: An average BST is relatively balanced, so you have to traverse around $log n$ nodes

best.explanation: In a balanced tree, you have to traverse $log n$ nodes.

all cases.explanation: Traversals visit all $n$ nodes in the tree.
Traversals visit all $n$ nodes in the tree.
Traversals visit all $n$ nodes in the tree.
Traversals visit all $n$ nodes in the tree.
Finding the height requires traversing the whole tree to find the deepest node.

worst.explanation: If everything hashes to the same index, we have to traverse the entire chain structure to check for duplicates, which is $O(n)$ for an SLL. The resize case is also $O(n)$ for an SLL.

average.explanation: $O(1)$ access to the hashed index and relatively few collisions.

best.explanation: $O(1)$ access to hashed index and there are no collisions.

worst.explanation: If everything hashes to the same index, we have to traverse the entire chain structure to find the entry, which is $O(n)$ for an SLL.
worst.example: [[0, 7, 14, 21], null, null, null, null, null, null] remove 21

average.explanation: $O(1)$ access to hashed index and relatively few collisions.

best.explanation: $O(1)$ access to hashed index and there are no collisions.

worst.explanation: If everything hashes to the same index, we have to traverse the entire chain structure. This is $O(n)$ for an SLL.
worst.example: [null, [1, 8, 15], null, null, null, null, null] find 15

average.explanation: $O(1)$ access to hashed index and relatively few collisions.

best.explanation: $O(1)$ access to hashed index and there are no collisions.

all cases.explanation: Resize by rehashing and adding $n$ elements to the new table, which is $O(1)$ each with an SLL chain. We do not have to check for duplicates when resizing.

worst.explanation: To resize, you have to rehash and copy all $n$ entries. For each entry, you may have to probe $n$ times if they all hash to the same index.
worst.example: A HashMap with hashcode function always returning 1.

average.explanation: With a good hash function, there are few or no collisions, so on average you just add the entry to the array at its hashed index.
average.example: Adding an entry with a key that has calculated index 7, and index 7 in the array is empty.

best.explanation: If there are no collisions, you can add the entry directly to its hashed index.
best.example: Adding an entry with a key that has calculated index 7, and index 7 in the array is empty.

worst.explanation: If every entry had the same hashcode, then when you want to remove an entry, you'd have to probe over every other entry.
worst.example: A HashMap with hashcode function always returning 1.

average.explanation: With a good hash function, there are few or no collisions, so on average you just remove the entry at its calculated index without probing.
average.example: Removing an entry with a key that has calculated index 7, and index 7 contains the key you're looking for.

best.explanation: If there are no collisions, remove the entry from its calculated index in the array.
best.example: Removing an entry with a key that has calculated index 7, and index 7 contains the key you're looking for.

worst.explanation: If every entry had the same hashcode, then when you want to find an entry, you'd have to probe over every other entry.
worst.example: A HashMap with hashcode function always returning 1.

average.explanation: With a good hash function, there are few or no collisions, so on average you can just find the entry at its calculated index without probing.
average.example: Finding an entry with a key that has calculated index 7, and index 7 contains the key you're looking for.

best.explanation: If there are no collisions, find the entry from its calculated index in the array.
best.example: Finding an entry with a key that has calculated index 7, and index 7 contains the key you're looking for.

worst.explanation: When resizing a Probing HashMap, each entry has the chance to probe over once more, causing a potential $n$ probes for each of $n$ entries.
worst.example: A Probing HashMap at full capacity, with a hash function that only returns 1.

average.explanation: There are generally few collisions after a resize. Copy all $n$ entries into their new spot in the resized array.
average.example: Each entry is copied over with there only being maybe 1 to 2 collisions.

best.explanation: In the best case, there are no collisions when resizing.
best.example: Each entry is copied over to the new array without any collisions.

worst.explanation: Each level requires a promotion, therefore $O(log n)$ promotions in addition to $O(log n)$ add.

average.explanation: Some promotions may be required after adding the element, but doing a promotion is $O(1)$ in addition to the $O(log n)$ addition.

best.explanation: No promotions required, just adding the element to a node.

worst.explanation: A transfer and/or fusion is required at each level, which is $O(log n)$ extra work on top of the $O(log n)$ remove.

average.explanation: Some transfers and/or fusions may be required, but either is $O(1)$ in addition to the $O(log n)$ remove.

best.explanation: No transfer or fusions required, just removing the element from a node.

worst.explanation: Element doesn't exist in tree, so we only traverse to $log n$ nodes before not finding element.

average.explanation: Most elements will exist at the bottom of the tree.

best.explanation: Element exists near top of tree.

all cases.explanation: All leaf nodes will exist at depth of $log n$.

worst.explanation: Each level requires a promotion, therefore $O(log n)$ promotions in addition to $O(log n)$ add.

average.explanation: Some promotions may be required after adding the element, but doing a promotion is $O(1)$ in addition to the $O(log n)$ addition.

best.explanation: No promotions required, just adding the element to a leaf node, which requires traversing $log n$ levels.

worst.explanation: A fusion is required at each level and propagates up, which is $O(log n)$ work plus the $O(log n)$ remove.

average.explanation: Some transfers and/or fusions may be required, but either is $O(1)$ in addition to the $O(log n)$ remove.

best.explanation: No transfer or fusions required. Must always traverse $log n$ levels to the leaf nodes, either to remove a leaf data or find a predecessor or successor.

worst.explanation: Element doesn't exist in tree, so we only traverse to $log n$ nodes before not finding element.

average.explanation: Most elements will exist at the bottom of the tree.

best.explanation: Element exists at the root of tree.

all cases.explanation: Because the tree is complete, all leaves are on the same (deepest) level. Traverse to any leaf node to find the height. A range of possible heights can be inferred using the number of data, but an exact answer requires traversal.

worst.explanation: When adding a new element, in the worst case, it bubbles up to the root through $logn$ levels.

worst (unamortized).explanation: In the resize case, we must copy all the data to a new larger array.

average.explanation: New elements typically bubble up through some of the heap's levels, logarithmically proportional to the size.

best.explanation: In the best case, the newly added data belongs in the leaf level and does not have to be bubbled up.

worst.explanation: After removing the root, the last element is put at the room and in the worst case must bubble down $logn$ levels.

average.explanation: The new root typically needs to bubble down through some of the heap's levels, logarithmically proportional to the size.

best.explanation: In the best case, we only have to downheap one level after swapping the last element to the root. This case is very rare.

all cases.explanation: Most nodes are near the bottom and require minimal adjustments. More specifically, about half of all data are on the leaf layer, and a quarter are on the second-to-last level, etc.

worst.explanation: Search for the insertion point at a leaf position, then perform at most one or two rotations. Since the tree is self-balancing, we never traverse more than $log n$ nodes.
worst.example: Current tree: [40, 30, 50, 20, null, null, null], Add 25

average.explanation: Search for the insertion point at a leaf position, then perform at most one or two rotations. Since the tree is self-balancing, we never traverse more than $log n$ nodes.

best.explanation: Even in an ideal case, we still must traverse down $log n$ nodes to find the correct insertion point and update balance factors back up to root.

worst.explanation: Search for the node, remove it, then rebalance up to root. May need to find a predecessor/successor at a leaf node. Each rotation is $O(1)$.
worst.example: Current tree: [6, 3, 9, null, 4, 7, 16, null, null, null, null, 11, null], Remove 6

average.explanation: Search for the node, remove it, then rebalance up to root. AVL property ensures we never have more than $log n$ nodes to traverse or fix.
average.example: Current tree: [40, 30, 50, 20, null, null, null], Remove 50

best.explanation: Even when removing a leaf node, we must still traverse down to it ($log n$) and update balance factors on the path back to root. When removing an internal/root node, we must find a predecessor/successor at a leaf node.

worst.explanation: Must traverse from root to leaf in a balanced tree. AVL property guarantees the height is $log n$, so we never check more than $log n$ nodes.

average.explanation: This is a binary search through a balanced tree. Each comparison eliminates half of remaining nodes, leading to $log n$ checks. Intuitively, most data is located towards the bottom of the tree, so we still have to traverse close to $log n$ levels.

best.explanation: Target value is at root node, requiring just one comparison and no traversal

all cases.explanation: Height is stored and maintained in each node as a property, requiring just a single field access

worst.explanation: With unlucky coin flips, the SkipList can become a multi-layered LinkedList, so you have to traverse it like a LinkedList. There is $O(n)$ data to traverse once, then $O(log n) layers to go straight down, which simplifies to $O(n)$,

average.explanation: With random coin probability, SkipList may not be perfectly symmetric, but on average traversing is $O(log n)$.

best.explanation: With perfectly distributed coin flips, SkipList is symmetric, so traversing is $O(log n)$.

worst.explanation: With unlucky coin flips, the SkipList can become a multi-layered LinkedList, so you have to traverse it like a LinkedList. There is $O(n)$ data to traverse once, then $O(log n) layers to go straight down, which simplifies to $O(n)$,

average.explanation: With random coin probability, SkipList may not be perfectly symmetric, but on average traversing is $O(log n)$.

best.explanation: With perfectly distributed coin flips, SkipList is symmetric, so traversing is $O(log n)$. You still need to traverse down $log n$ levels to remove.

worst.explanation: With unlucky coin flips, the SkipList can become a multi-layered LinkedList, so you have to traverse it like a LinkedList. There is $O(n)$ data to traverse once, then $O(log n) layers to go straight down, which simplifies to $O(n)$,

average.explanation: With random coin probability, SkipList may not be perfectly symmetric, but on average traversing takes $O(log n)$.

best.explanation: The data is found immediately.

worst.explanation: We compare every element to every other element, which is approximately $n$ times $n$ work.

average.explanation: On average, it performs more closely to its worst case.

best.explanation: If we have a separate boolean flag to check if the list is already sorted, we can detect this in one pass. Otherwise, this is $O(n²)$.

worst.explanation: Optimization has no effect on the worst-case.

average.explanation: While optimization does increase average runtime efficiency, it does not affect the time complexity.

best.explanation: The list is already sorted, which we can detect in one pass since the algorithm is adaptive.

worst.explanation: We may have to do up to $n$ swaps for each of $n$ items.

average.explanation: On average, it performs more closely to its worst case.

best.explanation: If we have a separate boolean flag to check if the list is already sorted, we can detect this in one pass. Otherwise, this is $O(n²)$.

worst.explanation: Optimization has no effect on the worst case.

average.explanation: While optimization does increase average runtime efficiency, it does not affect the time complexity.

best.explanation: The list is already sorted, which we can detect in one pass since the algorithm is adaptive.

worst.explanation: If the initial array is reverse-sorted, we have to move each element to the beginning of the array one spot at a time, which is approximately $n$ times $n$ work.

average.explanation: On average, it performs more closely to its worst case.

best.explanation: If the initial array is already sorted, we check each element once and do not have to move any towards the front.

all cases.explanation: Finding the largest or smallest element in the unsorted portion of the array requires $n$ comparisons, and we do this $n$ times.

worst.explanation: The worst pivot (min or max) is chosen each partition, devolving into a selection sort.

average.explanation: On average, the data is split roughly in half each partition.

best.explanation: The pivot is perfect (the median) in every partition.

worst.explanation: The minimum or maximum value of the subarray is always chosen.

average.explanation: Data is split in half on average during each partition. We can discard the partition which does not contain the target.

best.explanation: The pivot is always the median value of the subarray.

worst.explanation: Merge sort always recursively divides the array into halves (for a total of $log n$ levels) and merges each level (which is an $O(n)$ operation).
worst.example: [9, 2, 4, 5, 1, 8, 6, 3] divides into a total of 3 levels (log_2(8) = 3)

average.explanation: Merge sort always recursively divides the array into halves (for a total of $log n$ levels) and merges each level (which is an $O(n)$ operation).

best.explanation: Even in the best case, merge sort still recursively divides the array into halves (for a total of $log n$ levels) and merges each level (which is an $O(n)$ operation).

worst.explanation: One or a few numbers in the array are much longer than the rest. The longest number has $k$ digits.

average.explanation: Each number in the array will be added to and removed from a bucket $k$ times, where $k$ is the length of the longest number.

best.explanation: All of the numbers in the array have relatively few digits.

all cases.explanation: Removing an element from a heap is $O(log n)$, and we do this $n$ times.

worst.explanation: A mismatch occurs at the last comparison of the pattern to the text for every alignment.

best.explanation: The pattern is found in the text in the first alignment.

worst.explanation: A mismatch occurs at the last comparison of the pattern to the text for every alignment.

best.explanation: A mismatch always occurs at the first comparison for every alignment.

all cases.explanation: Building the Last Occurrence Table requires a linear pass through the pattern.

worst.explanation: When there is a mismatch on the first character of the pattern with a character of the text that exists in the pattern, shift by 1. If this happens for every alignment, the pattern will shift by 1 each time.

best.explanation: If every character of the text is not in the pattern, the pattern shifts by $m$ for each mismatch.

worst.explanation: The single occurrence is at the end of the text, requiring $n$ shifts

best.explanation: The pattern perfectly matches on the first alignment.

worst.explanation: When there is a mismatch on the first character of the pattern with a character of the text that exists in the pattern, shift by 1. If this happens for every alignment, the pattern will shift by 1 each time.

best.explanation: There is not a single character of the pattern in the text, causing shifts by $m$ each time.

all cases.explanation: Building the Failure Table requires a linear pass through the pattern.
In cases where no matches occur, the algorithm processes each character in the text and pattern once, plus the preprocessing time.

worst.explanation: KMP handles repeated pattern occurrences efficiently, scanning through the text in linear time, plus the preprocessing time.

best.explanation: When the pattern matches on the first alignment without any mismatches.

all cases.explanation: KMP handles repeated pattern occurrences efficiently, scanning through the text in linear time, plus the preprocessing time.
Calculate the hash of the pattern once, and then calculate the first $m$ characters of the text, for $O(2m)$ work.

worst.explanation: Assume pattern hash and text hash are always equal. Then there will be hash collisions for every substring to be compared, resulting in a brute-force approach. If every character except the last matches, then this is $O(mn)$ work.

best.explanation: Assume the hash of the pattern does not equal hash of text when strings are not equal. With no hash collisions, Rabin-Karp skips mismatches after rolling the hash.

worst.explanation: When there are many hash collisions due to a bad hash function, Rabin-Karp degenerates to $O(mn)$ as each substring must be compared.

best.explanation: The pattern matches on the first check after hash comparison, where we compare $m$ characters of the pattern and text.

worst.explanation: When hash collisions are frequent due to a bad hash function (i.e. every character hashes to 0), Rabin-Karp reverts to a brute-force comparison for each substring.

best.explanation: With a good hash function, there will be collisions only when the pattern and text match, thus Rabin-Karp efficiently finds all matches in linear time.

all cases.explanation: For each vertex, we iterate through all of its adjacent edges. Thus, we visit each vertex once and process each edge once.
all cases.example: A connects to B and C; B connects to D

all cases.explanation: For each vertex, we iterate through all of its adjacent edges. Thus, we visit each vertex once and process each edge once.
all cases.example: A connects to B and C; B connects to D

all cases.explanation: For each vertex, we iterate through all of its adjacent edges. Thus, we visit each vertex once and process each edge once.
all cases.example: A connects to B and C; B connects to D

all cases.explanation: For each vertex, we iterate through all of its adjacent edges like in BFS. We add edges to a priority queue to decide in what order to explore, which is logarithmic for each step (it uses a heap!)
all cases.example: A -(2)-> B; B -(2)-> C; A -(3)-> C: shortest path from A to C

all cases.explanation: For each vertex, we iterate through all of its adjacent edges like in BFS. We add edges to a priority queue to decide in what order to explore, which is logarithmic for each step (it uses a heap!)
all cases.example: A connects to B; B connects to C; C connects to A

all cases.explanation: We use a priority queue to incrementally add edges to the MST, which is logarithmic for each step (it uses a heap!)
all cases.example: A connects to B; B connects to C; C connects to A

all cases.explanation: Each letter in the first string is compared to each letter of the second string.
